title: Coordinate Plane Explorer
description: An interactive MicroSim that helps students understand the coordinate plane structure, including quadrants, axes, origin, and point location through hands-on exploration and quiz mode.
subject: Mathematics
prerequisites: Understanding of positive and negative numbers
Ability to read and write ordered pairs
learningObjectives: Identify and label the x-axis, y-axis, and origin on a coordinate plane
Understand the structure and numbering of the four quadrants
Plot points accurately using ordered pairs (x, y)
Determine which quadrant contains a given point
Recognize the sign patterns for coordinates in each quadrant
Use coordinates to describe the location of points on a plane
educationalStandards: CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.6.NS.C.6 - Understand rational numbers as points on the number line and in the coordinate plane
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.6.NS.C.8 - Solve problems by graphing points in all four quadrants
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.6.G.A.3 - Draw polygons in the coordinate plane
author: MicroSim Development Team

controls.label: Point
controls.description: Drag the red point anywhere on the coordinate plane to explore different coordinate positions

controls.label: Enter x
controls.description: Input field to enter the x-coordinate directly

controls.label: Enter y
controls.description: Input field to enter the y-coordinate directly

controls.label: Plot
controls.description: Plot the point at the coordinates entered in the input fields

controls.label: Random Point
controls.description: Generate and plot a random point on the coordinate plane

controls.label: Quiz Mode
controls.description: Toggle quiz mode where students are challenged to plot given coordinates

controls.label: Check Answer
controls.description: Check if the plotted point matches the quiz target (only visible in quiz mode)

controls.label: Quadrant Shading
controls.description: Toggle color-coded shading of the four quadrants

controls.label: Grid Lines
controls.description: Toggle visibility of grid lines for easier point placement

controls.label: Reference Lines
controls.description: Toggle dotted lines from the point to both axes

visualElements: Coordinate grid from -10 to 10 on both axes
Origin marked with dot and (0, 0) label
Quadrant labels (I, II, III, IV) in Roman numerals
Color-coded quadrant shading (I: light blue, II: light green, III: light yellow, IV: light pink)
Draggable red point with shadow effect
Dotted reference lines from point to axes
Real-time coordinate display with color coding
interactiveFeatures: Drag point to any location on the plane
Smooth animations when plotting new points
Direct coordinate entry via input fields
assessmentOpportunities: Quiz mode tracks correct vs. total attempts
Immediate feedback on coordinate plotting accuracy
Hints provided when answers are incorrect (which coordinate needs adjustment)
Observable student exploration patterns
Exit ticket: Successfully plot 3 points in quiz mode

accessibility.screenReader: Includes describe() function for screen reader support
accessibility.colorBlindSafe: Uses high contrast colors and multiple visual cues beyond color

commonMisconceptions.remedy: Color-coded display always shows x first; mnemonic 'x before y in alphabet'
Quadrant shading visually shows negative regions; incremental practice

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Points on axes belong to quadrants
commonMisconceptions.remedy: Clear 'On x-axis' or 'On y-axis' messages; discussion of quadrant definitions

extensionActivities: Plot points to create geometric shapes

technologyRequirements.devices: Desktop, laptop, tablet (700px width minimum recommended)

cognitiveLoadConsiderations.intrinsic: Coordinate system with four quadrants and signed numbers
cognitiveLoadConsiderations.extraneous: Minimized through clean interface and optional visual aids
cognitiveLoadConsiderations.germane: Focused on coordinate relationships and spatial reasoning

differentiationStrategies: Quadrant shading can be toggled for visual learners
Grid lines assist students who need more structure
Reference lines show explicit connections to axes
Quiz mode provides practice with immediate feedback
Random point generator offers unlimited practice opportunities

dublinCore.title: Integer Operations on the Number Line
creator: Dan McCreary
ChatGPT (GPT-5)
subject: Mathematics
Integers
Number Line
Arithmetic
dublinCore.description: An interactive p5.js simulation that visualizes integer addition and subtraction as movements on a horizontal number line. Users can click buttons to add or subtract values from -10 to +10, observing animated arrows and a cumulative equation.

learningObjectives: Visualize integer addition as movement to the right on a number line.
Visualize integer subtraction as movement to the left on a number line.
Interpret a cumulative arithmetic expression such as 0 + 3 - 2 + 4 = 5.
prerequisites: Understanding of positive and negative numbers

accessibility.screenReaderScript: Simulation that shows integer addition and subtraction as movement along a horizontal number line from -10 to +10. Blue circle shows current value, green arrows for addition, red arrows for subtraction.

controls.label: Add Buttons
controls.description: Adds positive integers (1–5) to the current position

controls.label: Subtract Buttons
controls.description: Subtracts positive integers (1–5) from the current position

controls.label: Reset
controls.description: Resets the simulation back to zero

visualElements.description: Horizontal number line from -10 to +10 with labeled tick marks
Green and red arrows animate integer addition and subtraction.
Displays current arithmetic equation (e.g., 0 + 3 - 2 + 4 = 5)

model.description: Integer arithmetic model representing cumulative addition and subtraction operations visualized as movements along a number line.
assumptions: Each operation changes the position by an integer step between -5 and +5.
Position range is clamped between -10 and +10.
limitations: Only supports integer values
Fixed range from -10 to +10

variables.name: currentPosition
variables.description: Current integer value on the number line

variables.name: equationParts
variables.description: String representation of the sequence of operations

events.name: operationPerformed
events.description: User clicked an Add or Subtract button

assessmentQuestions.question: If you start at -2 and add 4, what is your new position?
Explain why subtraction moves left on the number line.

extensions: Add sliders for variable step sizes
Include random problem generator for practice

title: Prime Factorization Tree Builder
description: Interactive tool for building factor trees to find prime factorization of composite numbers through step-by-step visual construction.
subject: Mathematics
learningObjectives: Build factor trees to decompose composite numbers into prime factors
Identify and distinguish between prime and composite numbers
Understand that prime factorization is unique for each number (Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic)
Apply divisibility rules to find factors efficiently
Express numbers in prime factorization form using exponential notation
bloomLevels: Remember: Recall prime numbers and divisibility rules
Understand: Explain the relationship between factors and prime factorization
Apply: Use divisibility rules to factor numbers systematically
Analyze: Compare different factorization paths leading to same result
Evaluate: Verify completeness and correctness of factorization
Create: Build complete factor trees for any composite number
prerequisites: Familiarity with prime and composite numbers
author: Claude (Anthropic AI)

controls.numberInput: Enter a number between 4 and 200 to factor
controls.randomNumber: Generate a random composite number at selected difficulty
controls.giveHint: Highlight a composite number and suggest divisibility rule
controls.showAnswer: Display the complete factorization tree with all prime factors
controls.clickNode: Click on blue (composite) nodes to enter two factors
controls.submitFactors: Validate and add factors to the tree

visualElements.edges: Lines connecting parent numbers to their factors
visualElements.primeList: Reference list of prime numbers up to 47
visualElements.divisibilityRules: Quick reference for divisibility by 2, 3, and 5

features: Show answer feature for complete factorization
pedagogicalApproach: Scaffolding through hints and reference materials
assessmentOpportunities: Predict prime factorization before building tree
Explain why different trees yield same factorization
Factor numbers with varying complexity
Identify patterns in factorizations
Apply divisibility rules efficiently
Compare factorization strategies
commonMisconceptions: Using 1 as a factor (prevented by validation)
Stopping factorization before reaching primes (visual feedback)
Entering incorrect factors (shake animation feedback)
Confusion about prime vs composite (color coding)
extensions: Compare different factorization paths for same number
Find GCF and LCM using prime factorizations
Explore perfect squares and their symmetric trees
Apply to finding square roots of perfect squares

dublinCore.title: Cognitive Bias Recognition Quiz
dublinCore.creator: Dan McCreary
subject: Ethics
Critical Thinking
Cognitive Psychology
Data Literacy
dublinCore.description: An interactive quiz game that presents real-world scenarios and asks students to identify which cognitive bias is being demonstrated. Includes 8 scenarios covering cherry picking, availability heuristic, ad hominem bias, anchoring, framing effect, survivorship bias, confirmation bias, and correlation-causation fallacy.

learningObjectives: Identify common cognitive biases in realistic scenarios
Distinguish between similar biases such as cherry picking and confirmation bias
Explain why specific reasoning patterns qualify as biased thinking
Apply bias recognition skills to evaluate arguments and data presentations
prerequisites: Basic understanding of what cognitive biases are
Familiarity with concepts of evidence and argumentation

controls.name: Option buttons
controls.description: Four multiple choice buttons for selecting the identified bias

controls.name: Show Hint
controls.description: Displays a hint to help identify the bias (reduces points from 10 to 5)

controls.name: Explain
controls.description: Shows detailed explanation of why the answer is correct

controls.name: Next Scenario
controls.description: Advances to the next quiz scenario

controls.name: Restart Quiz
controls.description: Resets the quiz with randomized question order

assumptions: Each scenario demonstrates one primary cognitive bias
Distractor options are plausible but distinguishable from correct answer
limitations: Real-world scenarios may involve multiple overlapping biases
Quiz format cannot capture nuanced understanding

learningObjectives: Understand the key concepts of this concept
Explore this concept through interactive visualization
Apply knowledge of this concept to solve problems
Test understanding of this concept through interactive exercises

title: Critical Thinking Framework for Ethical Analysis
description: An interactive circular infographic that guides students through a systematic critical thinking process for evaluating ethical claims and industry data.
creator: Dan McCreary
subject: Ethics
Critical Thinking
Data Literacy
Media Literacy

learningObjectives: Apply a systematic critical thinking process when evaluating ethical claims
Identify credibility indicators in data sources
Recognize potential biases and conflicts of interest
Distinguish between strong and weak evidence

controls.description: Click on any of the six segments to view detailed evaluation criteria with color-coded credibility indicators
Click the center circle to reset and evaluate a new claim
Press ESC to reset the view
Hover over segments to highlight them

segments.label: SOURCE
segments.question: Who is making this claim? What are their incentives?

segments.label: EVIDENCE
segments.question: What data supports this? Is it peer-reviewed?

segments.label: METHODOLOGY
segments.question: How was this measured? Are there biases?

segments.label: CONSISTENCY
segments.question: Does this align with other reliable sources?

segments.label: IMPLICATIONS
segments.question: What follows if this is true? Does that make sense?

assumptions: All six criteria are equally important for initial evaluation
Color coding provides intuitive credibility signals
limitations: Does not provide domain-specific evaluation criteria
Simplified model of complex critical thinking processes

learningObjectives: Understand the key concepts of critical thinking framework for ethical analysis
Explore critical thinking framework for ethical analysis through interactive visualization
Apply knowledge of critical thinking framework for ethical analysis to solve problems
Test understanding of critical thinking framework for ethical analysis through interactive exercises

Confusing distance formula with slope formula

title: Koch Fractal
creator: Generated with Claude Code
subject: Mathematics
Geometry
Fractals
Computer Science
description: An interactive visualization demonstrating the iterative construction of the Koch curve, a classic fractal with self-similar patterns at every scale. Students can adjust the recursion level from 0 to 6 to observe how simple iterative rules create complex fractal patterns.

learningObjectives: Understand how simple iterative rules can create complex patterns
Explore the concept of self-similarity in fractals
Observe how mathematical infinity can be approached through finite iterations
Connect geometric transformations with fractal generation
Calculate fractal dimensions and understand dimensions beyond integers
prerequisites: Basic understanding of line segments and geometric transformations
Familiarity with the concept of iteration
Knowledge of equilateral triangles (helpful but not required)

controls.name: recursionSlider
controls.label: Recursion Level
controls.purpose: Controls the number of iterations in the Koch curve construction. Level 0 shows a straight line, while higher levels show increasingly complex fractal patterns.

variables: baselineY: Vertical position of the fractal baseline
canvasWidth: Responsive width of the drawing canvas
model.algorithm: Recursive Koch curve generation using geometric transformation
model.description: At each recursion level, every line segment is divided into three equal parts, and the middle third is replaced with two sides of an equilateral triangle. This process creates a self-similar fractal pattern.
equations: Length at level n: (4/3)^n × original length
Number of segments at level n: 4^n
assumptions: The fractal is displayed as a 2D projection
Maximum recursion level is limited to 6 for performance
Discrete rendering approximates the theoretical continuous curve

dublin_core.title: Sierpinski Triangles
dublin_core.creator: Dan McCreary
subject: Mathematics
Geometry
Fractals
Recursion
Computer Science
dublin_core.description: An interactive visualization of the Sierpinski triangle fractal demonstrating recursive subdivision and self-similar patterns. Students can adjust the recursion depth from 0 to 7 levels to explore how simple rules create complex fractal patterns.

learning_objectives: Understand the concept of recursive subdivision in geometry
Analyze how fractals exhibit self-similarity at different scales
Explore the relationship between recursion depth and pattern complexity
Evaluate how mathematical infinity appears in finite visualizations
Calculate exponential growth in triangle counts (3^n)
prerequisites: Basic understanding of triangles and geometric shapes
Understanding of the concept of patterns

controls.label: Recursion Depth
controls.description: Controls the number of recursive subdivisions in the Sierpinski triangle pattern

parameters.name: currentDepth
parameters.purpose: Determines how many levels of recursion to apply when drawing the fractal

displays.label: Triangles
displays.description: Shows total number of triangles drawn (3^depth)

key_variables: recursionDepth - Number of recursive subdivisions to perform
vertices - Coordinates of triangle vertices for each recursion level
algorithm: - Create 4 smaller triangles from these midpoints
- Draw only the 3 outer triangles (skip center)
- Recursively apply to each of the 3 triangles
equations: Triangle count = 3^n where n is recursion depth
Total area approaches 0 as n approaches infinity
assumptions: Perfect geometric precision in subdivision
Equilateral starting triangle
Infinite recursion not practically achievable (limited to depth 7)
limitations: Performance degrades beyond depth 7 due to exponential triangle count
Does not show the mathematical properties of infinite recursion
Visual resolution limits ability to see very small triangles at high depths

ngss: HS-ETS1-4 - Use mathematics and computational thinking

title: Triangle Area Explorer

prerequisites: Understanding of units and square units

controls.name: Base Length Slider
controls.description: Adjusts the length of the triangle's base

controls.name: Height Slider
controls.description: Adjusts the perpendicular height of the triangle

controls.name: Reset Button
controls.description: Resets base and height to default values

parameters.name: triangleHeight
parameters.purpose: Perpendicular height from base to apex

assumptions: Triangle is drawn in 2D plane
Height is always perpendicular to base
Measurements use consistent arbitrary units
Triangle vertices remain within visible canvas
limitations: Does not show other triangle properties (angles, perimeter)
Limited to right-angle height visualization
Fixed scale factor for display
Does not cover triangle classification types

suggestedActivities: Pattern discovery: observe effects of doubling dimensions
Area challenge: find multiple base/height combinations for same area
Proportional reasoning: relationship between dimension and area changes
assessmentOpportunities: Calculate areas with given dimensions
Predict area changes from dimension changes
Identify base and height from triangle diagrams
Solve for unknown dimension given area and one dimension
commonMisconceptions: Height can be measured at any angle (must be perpendicular)
Area equals perimeter
Doubling both dimensions doubles area (actually quadruples)
Formula is bh instead of ½bh
discussionQuestions: Why is the formula ½bh instead of just bh?
What happens to area if you double both base and height?
Can two triangles with different dimensions have the same area?
How is triangle area related to rectangle area?

standardsAlignment: CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.6.G.A.1 - Find the area of triangles and polygons

microsim.title: ADDIE Workflow Interactive Model
microsim.description: Interactive visualization of the ADDIE instructional design model showing the five phases (Analysis, Design, Development, Implementation, Evaluation) and their iterative relationships. Users can click phases to explore details and see how designers cycle through the process.
microsim.subject: Instructional Design
learning_objectives: Identify the five phases of the ADDIE instructional design model
Explain the purpose and key tasks of each ADDIE phase
Understand that instructional design is an iterative process
Recognize when to cycle back to earlier phases based on findings
prerequisites: Basic understanding of educational content creation
microsim.author: Intelligent Textbooks Project

controls.name: Phase Nodes
controls.description: Click on any of the five colored circles to view detailed tasks for that phase

controls.name: Show Iteration Arrows
controls.description: Toggle display of arrows showing how designers can return to earlier phases

controls.name: Show Task Checkboxes
controls.description: Display individual tasks within each phase as checkable items

controls.name: Animate Flow
controls.description: Start/stop animation showing progression through ADDIE phases

controls.name: Reset All
controls.description: Reset all selections and animations to initial state

controls.name: Animation Speed
controls.description: Control the speed of the flow animation

assessment_suggestions: Ask students to identify which phase specific tasks belong to
Have students describe scenarios requiring iteration back to earlier phases
Request examples of how each phase would apply to a specific project
Ask students to sequence the phases and explain the rationale
extension_activities: Compare ADDIE to other instructional design models (SAM, Agile)
Create a detailed project plan using ADDIE for a specific learning objective
Analyze case studies showing successful and unsuccessful use of ADDIE
Develop checklists for each phase customized to your content area

accessibility.described_content: Interactive ADDIE workflow diagram with clickable phases showing Analysis, Design, Development, Implementation, and Evaluation

references: Branch, R. M. (2009). Instructional Design: The ADDIE Approach. Springer.
Morrison, G. R., Ross, S. J., Morrison, J. R., & Kalman, H. K. (2019). Designing Effective Instruction (8th ed.). Wiley.
Dick, W., Carey, L., & Carey, J. O. (2014). The Systematic Design of Instruction (8th ed.). Pearson.

microsim.title: Cognitive Load Visualizer
microsim.description: Interactive visualization demonstrating the three types of cognitive load (intrinsic, extraneous, and germane) and their impact on working memory capacity. Users can adjust sliders to see how different load combinations affect learning effectiveness and explore optimal instructional design configurations.
microsim.subject: Educational Psychology
learning_objectives: Identify and distinguish between the three types of cognitive load
Explain how each type of cognitive load affects learning outcomes
Recognize when total cognitive load exceeds working memory capacity
Apply cognitive load principles to evaluate instructional design
Design learning materials that optimize cognitive load
prerequisites: Basic understanding of how learning works
microsim.author: Intelligent Textbooks Project

controls.name: Intrinsic Load
controls.description: Adjust the inherent difficulty of the content being learned

controls.name: Extraneous Load
controls.description: Adjust the mental effort wasted on poor instructional design

controls.name: Germane Load
controls.description: Adjust the mental effort devoted to learning processes

controls.name: Good Design Example
controls.description: Load an example showing optimal cognitive load balance

controls.name: Bad Design Example
controls.description: Load an example showing cognitive overload

controls.name: Reset to Default
controls.description: Return all sliders to their default values

feedback_mechanisms: Color changes (blue/orange/red) based on load level

assessment_suggestions: Ask students to identify which type of load each design element creates
Have students calculate total load from given scenarios
Request redesign of high-load materials to reduce extraneous load
Ask students to justify load estimates for specific learning materials
Have students create load profiles for different learner expertise levels
extension_activities: Analyze real textbooks or courses for cognitive load issues
Create before/after designs showing load reduction
Research how expertise changes intrinsic load
Design a study to measure cognitive load in learners
Apply multimedia learning principles to reduce extraneous load

theoretical_foundation.developers: John Sweller, Paul Chandler, Fred Paas
key_principles: Working memory has limited capacity (typically 4-7 chunks)
Long-term memory has virtually unlimited capacity
Learning requires transferring information from working to long-term memory
Cognitive load is additive across all three types
Effective design manages all three types of load
research_support: Meta-analyses show effect sizes of 0.4-1.0 for load reduction
Split-attention effect consistently demonstrates extraneous load impact
Worked example effect shows intrinsic load management
Expertise reversal effect demonstrates load relativity

common_misconceptions: More information is always better (ignores capacity limits)
Attractive design is more important than clear design (adds extraneous load)
All cognitive effort is productive (ignores extraneous load)
Content difficulty can't be managed (ignores chunking strategies)

accessibility.described_content: Interactive cognitive load visualizer with three adjustable load types and a capacity meter showing when working memory is overloaded

references: Sweller, J., Ayres, P., & Kalyuga, S. (2011). Cognitive Load Theory. Springer.
Mayer, R. E. (2021). Multimedia Learning (3rd ed.). Cambridge University Press.
van Merriënboer, J. J. G., & Sweller, J. (2005). Cognitive load theory and complex learning. Educational Psychology Review, 17(2), 147-177.
Paas, F., Renkl, A., & Sweller, J. (2003). Cognitive load theory and instructional design: Recent developments. Educational Psychologist, 38(1), 1-4.

microsim.title: Kemp Design Model Interactive Visualization
microsim.description: Interactive visualization of the Kemp Design Model, a flexible instructional design framework with nine interconnected elements arranged in a circle. Users can click any element to explore details and see connections, emphasizing the model's non-linear, holistic approach where designers can start anywhere and move in any direction.
microsim.subject: Instructional Design
learning_objectives: Identify the nine elements of the Kemp Design Model
Explain how Kemp differs from linear models like ADDIE
Understand the flexible, non-sequential nature of the model
Recognize how all elements interconnect and influence each other
Apply Kemp's holistic approach to instructional design projects
Determine appropriate starting points for different project types
prerequisites: Familiarity with at least one other design model (ADDIE recommended)
Understanding of learning objectives and assessment
microsim.author: Intelligent Textbooks Project

controls.name: Nine Element Circles
controls.description: Click any of the nine colored circles to view detailed information about that element

controls.name: Show All Connections
controls.description: Toggle to display lines showing how all elements interconnect

controls.name: Animate Connections
controls.description: Animate the connection lines to show data flow

controls.name: Reset Selection
controls.description: Clear the selected element and close the details panel

assessment_suggestions: Ask students to identify which element they would start with for different projects
Have students explain how changing one element affects others
Request comparison of Kemp with ADDIE or SAM for specific scenarios
Ask students to sequence elements for a given project and justify the order
Have students identify which elements are most interconnected
extension_activities: Map a real project to the nine Kemp elements
Create a Kemp-based project plan showing element interdependencies
Compare Kemp to other circular/systems models
Develop checklists for each Kemp element
Interview instructional designers about which elements they address first

key_principles: Holistic systems perspective on instructional design
All elements are interconnected and interdependent
Designers can start at any point based on project needs
Continuous revision of elements as information emerges

element_1.name: Instructional Problems
element_1.description: Identify what learners need to know or be able to do
key_questions: What gaps exist in current performance?
What learning needs must be addressed?

element_2.name: Learner Characteristics
element_2.description: Examine who your learners are and what they bring
key_questions: What prior knowledge do learners have?

element_3.name: Task Analysis
element_3.description: Determine subject content and skills to be learned
key_questions: What specific content must be covered?
What skills need to be developed?

element_4.name: Instructional Objectives
key_questions: What will learners be able to do after instruction?

element_5.name: Content Sequencing
element_5.description: Arrange content in logical, effective order
key_questions: In what order should concepts be taught?

element_6.name: Instructional Strategies
element_6.description: Design teaching methods and learning activities
key_questions: What teaching methods will be most effective?
How will learners engage with content?

element_7.name: Instructional Delivery
element_7.description: Plan how instruction will be delivered
key_questions: What delivery format is most appropriate?

element_8.name: Evaluation Instruments
key_questions: What evaluation methods align with objectives?

element_9.name: Support Services
key_questions: What budget and timeline constraints exist?

model_characteristics.iteration: Continuous revision of any element at any time

vs_sam.kemp_advantage: Holistic view of all factors simultaneously

challenges: Can feel less structured than ADDIE
Requires discipline to address all elements
May confuse stakeholders expecting linear process
Easy to neglect elements due to flexibility
success_factors: Regular reviews of all nine elements

accessibility.described_content: Interactive Kemp Design Model with nine clickable elements arranged in a circle, showing descriptions, examples, and interconnections between all elements

references: Kemp, J. E., Morrison, G. R., & Ross, S. M. (1998). Designing Effective Instruction (3rd ed.). Prentice Hall.
Morrison, G. R., Ross, S. J., Morrison, J. R., & Kalman, H. K. (2019). Designing Effective Instruction (8th ed.). Wiley.
Branch, R. M., & Dousay, T. A. (2015). Survey of Instructional Design Models (5th ed.). AECT.
Gustafson, K. L., & Branch, R. M. (2002). Survey of Instructional Development Models (4th ed.). ERIC.

microsim.title: SAM: Successive Approximation Model Process
microsim.description: Interactive visualization of the Successive Approximation Model (SAM), an agile instructional design approach. Watch how quality improves through iterative cycles of design and development, with rapid prototyping and continuous stakeholder feedback replacing traditional linear processes.
microsim.subject: Instructional Design
learning_objectives: Identify the three phases of the SAM process (Preparation, Iterative Design, Iterative Development)
Explain how SAM differs from traditional ADDIE approach
Understand the value of rapid prototyping and iteration
Recognize how product quality improves through successive iterations
Apply SAM principles to real instructional design projects
microsim.author: Intelligent Textbooks Project

controls.name: Auto-play Iterations
controls.description: Automatically progress through all iterations without manual clicking

controls.name: Next Iteration
controls.description: Manually advance to the next phase in the SAM process

controls.name: Reset Process
controls.description: Return to the beginning of the SAM process

controls.name: Iteration Speed
controls.description: Control how fast the iterations progress in auto-play mode

visual_representations: Spiral path visualization showing iterative cycles

assessment_suggestions: Ask students to compare SAM and ADDIE for a specific project scenario
Have students identify which phase specific activities belong to
Request students to explain when to use SAM vs. ADDIE
Ask students to describe how quality improves through iterations
Have students plan a SAM project with specific iteration goals
extension_activities: Design a Savvy Start workshop agenda for a real project
Create rapid prototypes using paper or digital tools
Analyze a failed project and propose how SAM could have helped
Compare time and cost estimates for ADDIE vs. SAM approaches
Interview practitioners about their experiences with SAM

key_principles: Test early and often with real learners
Embrace change as part of the process

prototyping.sam: Early and frequent from day one

stakeholder_involvement.addie: Primarily at analysis and evaluation phases

best_for.sam: Unclear requirements, need speed, innovation valued
best_for.addie: Clear requirements, compliance needs, fixed scope

preparation.name: Preparation Phase
activities: Gather information about learners and context
preparation.deliverable: Project brief and initial design ideas

iterative_design.name: Iterative Design Phase
activities: Review with stakeholders in collaborative sessions
Refine design based on stakeholder input

savvy_start_workshop.description: Intensive collaborative design workshop that kicks off SAM projects
savvy_start_workshop.outcome: Aligned team with validated design direction and working prototypes

quality_progression.description: Quality improves with each iteration but with diminishing returns

iteration_1.descriptor: Initial rough draft, functional but unpolished

iteration_2.descriptor: Improved based on feedback, clearer direction

iteration_3.descriptor: More polished and effective, refined features

iteration_4.descriptor: Fine-tuned with user input, near production quality

iteration_5.descriptor: High-quality finished product, ready for deployment

common_pitfalls.solution: Schedule regular review sessions with all stakeholders
Set strict time limits and move to prototyping quickly
Define 'good enough' criteria upfront and stick to them
Make testing with real learners mandatory in each cycle
Invest in rapid prototyping tools and train team members

accessibility.described_content: Interactive SAM process visualizer showing three phases with spiral path, quality improvement tracking, and iterative progression through design and development cycles

references: Allen, M. W., & Sites, R. (2012). Leaving ADDIE for SAM: An Agile Model for Developing the Best Learning Experiences. ASTD Press.
Allen, M. W. (2016). Designing Successful e-Learning: Forget What You Know About Instructional Design and Do Something Interesting. Pfeiffer.
Hnatiuk, J. (2021). SAM for Instructional Designers. ATD Press.
Branch, R. M. (2009). Instructional Design: The ADDIE Approach. Springer.

subject: Graph Databases
Information Science

dublinCore.description: An interactive visualization demonstrating the three layers of data transformation: Data Layer (raw binary), Information Layer (isolated facts), and Knowledge Layer (connected graph). Hover over each layer to learn about its characteristics.

educational.topic: Graph Database Fundamentals, Knowledge Representation, Data Transformation
learningObjectives: Understand the progression from raw data to actionable knowledge
Identify the characteristics that distinguish data, information, and knowledge
Explain why connected information (knowledge graphs) provides more value than isolated facts
Relate the knowledge triangle concept to graph database architectures

interactivity.description: Hover over any of the three triangle layers to display an informational tooltip explaining that layer's characteristics

visualElements.appearance: Black background with bright green 1s and 0s (terminal style)

visualElements.purpose: Represents isolated facts extracted from data

visualElements.appearance: Connected graph with nodes and edges in various colors
visualElements.purpose: Represents connected facts forming a knowledge graph

assumptions: Data volume decreases as semantic value increases moving up the triangle
Knowledge emerges from connections between information, not from isolated facts
Graph structure is the natural representation of the knowledge layer
simulationModel.pedagogicalPurpose: Help students understand why graph databases are valuable by visualizing how connected information (knowledge graphs) differs fundamentally from raw data and isolated facts

title: Minimum Spanning Tree Algorithm Visualizer
creator: Claude Code AI Assistant
subject: Computer Science
Graph Theory
Algorithms
Data Structures
description: Interactive visualization demonstrating Kruskal's and Prim's algorithms for finding minimum spanning trees in weighted graphs. Students can step through algorithm execution, compare approaches, and understand cycle detection in network optimization.
learningObjectives: Understand the minimum spanning tree problem and its applications
Compare Kruskal's edge-based and Prim's node-based algorithmic approaches
Analyze how greedy algorithms make locally optimal choices
Observe cycle detection mechanisms using union-find data structures
Apply graph theory concepts to real-world network optimization problems
prerequisites: Familiarity with greedy algorithms (helpful but not required)

accessibility.screenReader: ARIA labels provided via p5 describe() function
accessibility.colorblindSafe: High contrast colors used for edge states

controls.name: Algorithm Selection
controls.description: Choose between Kruskal's (edge-based) or Prim's (node-based) algorithm

controls.name: Step Forward
controls.description: Execute one algorithm step to observe decision-making process

controls.name: Auto Run
controls.description: Automatically animate complete algorithm execution

controls.name: Reset
controls.description: Generate new random graph and restart simulation

controls.name: Animation Speed
controls.description: Control delay between algorithm steps for learning pace

variables: nodes - graph vertices with positions and labels
edges - graph edges with weights and states
mstEdges - edges accepted into minimum spanning tree
parent - union-find structure for Kruskal's cycle detection
visited - node tracker for Prim's algorithm
priorityQueue - candidate edges for Prim's algorithm
equations: MST weight = sum of all accepted edge weights
Greedy choice: min(available edges satisfying constraints)
assumptions: Graph is connected (all nodes reachable from any starting node)
Edge weights are positive integers (50-200 range)
8 nodes with ~15 edges provides good visualization
Both algorithms always find an MST (may differ in edge selection order)
limitations: Does not handle disconnected graphs
Does not visualize internal data structures (union-find tree, priority queue)
Random graph generation may create varying difficulty levels
Cannot create custom graphs interactively
realWorldApplications: Supply chain and distribution network design

creator: Claude Code
Dan McCreary
subject: Physics
Dynamics
Newton's Laws
Classical Mechanics
dublinCore.description: Interactive simulation demonstrating Newton's Third Law through six real-world scenarios: book on table, hammer and nail, rocket propulsion, swimming, Earth-Moon gravitation, and car acceleration. Each scenario visualizes action-reaction force pairs with animated graphics and explanatory panels.

educational.topic: Newton's Third Law, Action-Reaction Pairs, Force Interactions
learningObjectives: Identify action-reaction force pairs in various physical situations
Explain why action-reaction pairs do not cancel each other out
Distinguish between contact forces and gravitational forces
Apply Newton's Third Law to explain rocket propulsion
Recognize that action-reaction pairs act on different objects
Understand that action-reaction forces are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction
educational.prerequisites: Basic understanding of forces, Newton's First and Second Laws

controls.name: Book
controls.description: Shows book on table scenario with gravity and normal force pairs

controls.name: Hammer
controls.description: Shows hammer and nail scenario demonstrating equal forces, different accelerations

controls.name: Rocket
controls.description: Shows rocket propulsion through gas exhaust reaction

controls.name: Swim
controls.description: Shows swimmer pushing water to move forward

controls.name: Gravity
controls.description: Shows Earth-Moon gravitational attraction as mutual

controls.name: Car
controls.description: Shows car acceleration through tire-ground interaction

controls.name: Highlight Action-Reaction Pairs
controls.description: Toggle visibility of force vector arrows

scenarios: Book on Table: Two action-reaction pairs (gravity, contact)
Hammer and Nail: Equal forces, different masses
Rocket in Space: Propulsion via momentum conservation
Swimming: Push water back, move forward
Car Accelerating: Tire pushes ground, ground pushes tire
keyPrinciples: Action-reaction pairs are always equal in magnitude
Action-reaction pairs always act on different objects
Action-reaction pairs are always the same type of force
Weight and normal force are NOT an action-reaction pair

commonMisconceptions: Action-reaction forces cancel out (they act on different objects)
Larger objects exert larger forces (forces are always equal)
Weight and normal force are an action-reaction pair (they're not)
You need something to push against to move (rockets work in vacuum)
assessmentOpportunities: Identify the two objects involved in each action-reaction pair
Explain why a hammer drives a nail despite equal forces
Describe how a rocket moves in the vacuum of space
Distinguish between action-reaction pairs and balanced forces
realWorldApplications: Sports: pushing off in running, jumping, skating

microsim.title: Metric Scale Zoom
microsim.name: metric-scale-zoom
microsim.description: An interactive MicroSim that helps students visualize the relative scale of metric prefixes and practice conversions between different orders of magnitude, from nanometers to exameters.
microsim.author: Dan McCreary
microsim.subject: Physics, Mathematics, Measurement
prerequisites: Basic understanding of the metric system
learningObjectives: Recognize common metric prefixes and their corresponding powers of 10
Understand the logarithmic nature of the metric system
Apply appropriate metric units to describe objects of different sizes
Analyze the relative scale differences between everyday objects and astronomical features
Evaluate which metric prefix is most appropriate for a given measurement
standards: NGSS: Measurement and data, scale and proportion
Common Core Math: Understanding place value and powers of 10

controls.name: Zoom Level
controls.description: Adjusts the scale level from nanometers to exameters
controls.purpose: Navigate through different orders of magnitude

parameters.name: currentObjectIndex
parameters.description: Index of the currently displayed object

parameters.name: scaleObjects
parameters.description: Array of objects at different metric scales

assumptions: Objects are represented at approximate typical sizes
Scale transitions are discrete steps rather than continuous zoom
Logarithmic scale provides equal visual spacing for exponential changes
limitations: Only shows 10 discrete scale levels
Does not include all possible metric prefixes
Object sizes are approximations for educational purposes
Does not demonstrate actual size conversions between all units

assessmentOpportunities: Identify appropriate metric prefixes for given measurements
Convert between different metric units
Explain the relationship between metric prefixes and powers of 10
Estimate relative sizes across different scales
commonMisconceptions: Thinking metric prefixes increase linearly rather than logarithmically
Confusing the order or meaning of metric prefixes
Not understanding that each prefix represents a specific power of 10
extensionActivities: Research additional objects that fit on the scale
Connect logarithmic scale to scientific notation
Practice unit conversions across multiple scales

dublinCore.title: Projectile Motion Simulation
creator: Claude Code
Dan McCreary
subject: Physics
Kinematics
Classical Mechanics
dublinCore.description: Interactive simulation demonstrating parabolic trajectories of projectiles with adjustable launch angle and power. Features visual cannon, trajectory tracing, and multiple shot comparison.

learningObjectives: Describe the trajectory of a projectile as parabolic
Explain how launch angle affects range and maximum height
Understand independence of horizontal and vertical motion
Predict optimal angle for maximum range
Apply velocity component decomposition
Analyze the effect of initial velocity on projectile motion
educational.prerequisites: Basic understanding of velocity, acceleration, and gravity

controls.name: angleSlider
controls.label: Angle
controls.description: Launch angle of the cannon from horizontal

controls.name: powerSlider
controls.label: Power
controls.description: Initial velocity/power of the projectile

controls.name: fireButton
controls.label: Fire
controls.description: Launch a projectile with current angle and power settings

controls.name: resetButton
controls.label: Reset
controls.description: Clear all trajectory traces from the canvas

displays.name: cannon
displays.description: Animated cannon that rotates to match the selected angle

displays.name: trajectories
displays.description: Dashed lines showing parabolic paths of all fired projectiles

displays.name: angleIndicator
displays.description: Numerical display of current angle near cannon barrel

equations: y = y₀ + vy × t + 0.5 × g × t²
assumptions: No air resistance (ideal projectile motion)
Constant gravitational acceleration
Point mass projectile (no rotation or size effects)
Flat, level ground
2D motion only (no side-to-side wind)
Instantaneous launch (no barrel friction)
limitations: Does not model air resistance or drag
Ignores Magnus effect (spin-induced curves)
No terrain variation
Simplified gravity (no variation with altitude)
Does not account for Earth's rotation (Coriolis effect)
2D simulation of a 3D phenomenon

commonMisconceptions: Heavier objects fall faster (in vacuum, all objects fall at same rate)
Horizontal motion affects vertical motion (they are independent)
Projectiles move in a straight line then fall (motion is always curved)
Maximum range always occurs at 45° (true only without air resistance)
assessmentOpportunities: Predict landing distance for given angle and power
Identify optimal angle for maximum range
Explain complementary angle phenomenon (30° and 60°)
Calculate time of flight using physics equations
Compare simulation results to theoretical calculations
realWorldApplications: Engineering: water fountain design, package delivery drones

learningObjectives: Understand the key concepts of this concept
Explore this concept through interactive visualization
Apply knowledge of this concept to solve problems
Experiment with parameters to observe their effects on this concept

dublinCore.title: Projectile Motion with Gravity MicroSim
creator: Educational MicroSim Generator
Claude AI Assistant
subject: Physics
Mechanics
Kinematics
Projectile Motion
Gravity
dublinCore.description: An interactive simulation demonstrating how gravity affects the parabolic trajectory of projectiles. Students can adjust gravity values and observe multiple trajectories to understand the relationship between gravitational acceleration and projectile motion.
relation: NGSS: MS-PS2-1
NGSS: MS-PS2-2
NGSS: HS-PS2-1
Common Core Math: HSF-IF.B.4
Common Core Math: HSF-IF.C.7
dublinCore.rights: CC BY 4.0 - Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International

learningObjectives: Understand that gravity affects the vertical motion of projectiles
Apply concepts of parabolic motion to predict trajectory shapes
Analyze how changes in gravity affect projectile range and height
Evaluate the relationship between gravitational acceleration and trajectory characteristics
Compare projectile motion under different gravitational conditions
prerequisites: Basic understanding of gravity as a force
Understanding that objects can have both horizontal and vertical motion

curriculumStandards.description: Apply Newton's Third Law to design a solution to a problem involving the motion of two colliding objects
Plan an investigation to provide evidence that the change in an object's motion depends on the sum of forces
Analyze data to support the claim that Newton's second law of motion describes the mathematical relationship
Interpret key features of graphs and tables in terms of the quantities
Graph functions expressed symbolically and show key features

controls.label: Fire
controls.description: Launches a new projectile from the cannon

controls.label: Reset
controls.description: Clears all projectile trajectories from the screen

controls.label: Gravity
controls.description: Adjusts the gravitational acceleration affecting projectile motion

visualElements.description: Cannon positioned in lower left corner
Projectile trajectories with dashed lines
Current gravity value and trajectory count

model.description: Classical mechanics model of projectile motion under constant gravitational acceleration. Uses kinematic equations to calculate position based on initial velocity components and gravitational acceleration.
algorithms: Euler method for numerical integration of position and velocity
Dashed line rendering algorithm for trajectory visualization
assumptions: No air resistance (vacuum conditions)
Constant gravitational acceleration throughout trajectory
Flat, level ground surface
Point mass projectile (no rotation or spin)
Fixed launch angle of 45 degrees
Fixed initial velocity of 15 m/s
limitations: Does not model air resistance or drag
Does not account for Earth's rotation (Coriolis effect)
Does not model wind effects
Simplified 2D model (no lateral deviation)
Does not show energy calculations explicitly
Ground is perfectly level (no terrain variation)

variables.name: projectile.velocityY
variables.description: Vertical velocity component (changes due to gravity)

events.name: projectileFired
events.description: User clicked Fire button to launch projectile

events.name: simulationReset
events.description: User clicked Reset button to clear trajectories

events.name: sessionEnd
events.description: User closed or left the simulation

metrics.name: engagementTime
metrics.description: Total time spent interacting with simulation

metrics.name: explorationDiversity
metrics.calculation: Standard deviation of gravity values used

metrics.name: trajectoryComparisons
metrics.description: Number of trajectories visible before reset
metrics.calculation: Count of projectiles when reset clicked

metrics.name: parameterAdjustmentFrequency
metrics.description: How often gravity was adjusted per minute
metrics.calculation: Count of gravityAdjusted events / total minutes

instructionalStrategies: Start with prediction: Have students predict trajectory shape before firing
Compare extremes: Show minimum and maximum gravity to establish range
Connect to real world: Compare Earth, Moon, and Mars gravity settings
Use inquiry questions: 'What stays constant? What changes?'
Facilitate discussion: Ask students to explain observations to peers
Progressive complexity: Start with single trajectory, then compare multiple

assessmentQuestions.question: What force causes projectiles to follow a curved path?
Explain why the projectile eventually comes back down to the ground.
If gravity were doubled, would the projectile travel farther or less far? Explain.
Compare the trajectories at 0.5 m/s² and 1.5 m/s². What is the approximate ratio of their horizontal ranges?
In the real world, how would air resistance affect these trajectories? Would it make the simulation more or less accurate?
Design an experiment using this simulation to determine the optimal launch angle for maximum range. What would you test?

extensions: Add a slider to control launch angle and find optimal angle for maximum range
Include initial velocity control to explore how speed affects trajectory
Add air resistance to show real-world effects
Display numerical data: max height, range, time of flight
Add energy calculations and graphs (kinetic and potential)
Create target zones for accuracy challenges
Model trajectories on different planets with actual gravity values
Add wind effects that vary over time

Dan McCreary
subject: Physics
Chemistry

dublinCore.description: Interactive simulation demonstrating the relationship between temperature, molecular motion, and gas pressure with visual ice/fire indicators and dual temperature scale support.

controls.name: temperatureSlider
controls.label: Temperature
controls.purpose: Adjust the temperature of the gas, affecting molecular speed and collision frequency

controls.name: startButton
controls.label: Start Simulation / Pause Simulation
controls.purpose: Toggle simulation running state. Starts paused to allow users to set initial conditions before observing molecular motion.

controls.name: temperatureScale
controls.label: Temperature Scale
controls.purpose: Switch between Celsius and Fahrenheit temperature scales

displays.name: Wall Hits/sec
displays.purpose: Shows collision frequency as a direct indicator of gas pressure

displays.name: Ice/Fire Region
displays.purpose: Visual indicator showing ice cubes below 0°C and flames above 0°C

displays.name: Atom Colors
displays.purpose: Atoms change from blue (cold) to red (hot) based on temperature

simulation.modelType: Molecular dynamics - kinetic theory of gases

variables.name: temperature
variables.description: Temperature in Celsius (internally), affects molecular speed

variables.name: numAtoms
variables.description: Number of gas atoms in chamber (fixed)

variables.name: collisionsPerSecond
variables.description: Number of wall collisions per second (pressure indicator)

equations.name: Velocity-Temperature Relationship
equations.description: Molecular speed increases linearly with temperature

equations.name: Kinetic Energy
equations.description: Kinetic energy is proportional to absolute temperature

assumptions: Elastic collisions with walls (no energy loss)
No inter-molecular collisions modeled (simplified)
2D simulation of 3D phenomenon
Linear relationship between temperature and speed for educational clarity
Constant chamber volume
limitations: Does not model inter-molecular attractions (van der Waals forces)
Simplified pressure calculation (wall hits only, not force)
No modeling of phase changes beyond visual indicator
2D representation of 3D molecular motion
Does not account for relativistic effects at extreme speeds

dublinCore.title: Triangle Type Explorer
dublinCore.creator: Claude Code with Dan McCreary MicroSim Framework
dublinCore.subject: Geometry, Triangle Classification
dublinCore.description: An interactive MicroSim that allows students to explore triangle types by dragging vertices. Real-time classification by side lengths (Equilateral, Isosceles, Scalene) and angles (Acute, Right, Obtuse).

learningObjectives: Identify the three types of triangles based on side lengths (Equilateral, Isosceles, Scalene)
Recognize the three types of triangles based on angles (Acute, Right, Obtuse)
Understand the relationship between side lengths and triangle classification
Explore how changing vertex positions affects triangle properties
Apply classification knowledge to categorize triangles based on their characteristics
prerequisites: Understanding of basic geometry concepts (points, lines, triangles)
Familiarity with angle measurement in degrees
standards: CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.7.G.A.2 - Draw triangles with given measurements
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.HSG.CO.B.8 - Understand congruence in terms of rigid motions
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.HSG.SRT.A.1 - Understand similarity in terms of similarity transformations

controls.description: Three draggable red circles (A, B, C) that define the triangle vertices
controls.interaction: Click and drag to move vertices to any position
controls.purpose: Primary mechanism for exploring different triangle types

displays.name: Triangle Classification Label
displays.description: Large text showing combined classification (e.g., 'Isosceles Right')

displays.name: Angle Measures
displays.description: Displays calculated angles at each vertex
displays.location: Upper left of canvas, below side lengths

variables.name: Vertex A
variables.description: Position (x, y) of the first triangle vertex

variables.name: Vertex B
variables.description: Position (x, y) of the second triangle vertex

variables.name: Vertex C
variables.description: Position (x, y) of the third triangle vertex

variables.name: Side a
variables.description: Length of side opposite vertex A (BC)

variables.name: Side b
variables.description: Length of side opposite vertex B (AC)

variables.name: Side c
variables.description: Length of side opposite vertex C (AB)

assumptions: Triangles are always valid (cannot become degenerate)
Measurements are rounded to one decimal place for display
Tolerance of 2 pixels used to determine if sides are 'equal'
Tolerance of 5 degrees used to determine if angle is 'right'
limitations: Does not prevent extremely distorted triangles
Does not show construction steps (purely exploratory)
Assumes Euclidean geometry (flat 2D space)

bestPractices: Use as an exploration tool before formal instruction on triangle types
Have students predict triangle type before dragging vertices
Ask students to create specific triangle types within time limits
Use for homework practice and self-assessment
Connect to real-world examples of triangle types in structures
assessmentOpportunities: Can students identify triangle types from visual display?
Can students create specific triangle types on demand?
Do students understand relationships between sides and angles?
Can students explain why certain combinations are impossible (e.g., Equilateral Right)?
commonMisconceptions: Confusing side-based classification with angle-based classification
Thinking all right triangles are isosceles
Believing obtuse triangles cannot be isosceles
Not understanding that angles must sum to 180°
extensions: Calculate and display perimeter and area
Connect to trigonometric ratios (sin, cos, tan)

deployment.notes: Can be embedded in any website or learning management system. Code is fully compatible with p5.js editor for easy modification.

Explore this concept through interactive visualization
Apply knowledge of this concept to solve problems
Experiment with parameters to observe their effects on this concept

bloomsTaxonomy: Remember - Recall definitions of triangle types
Understand - Explain properties of different triangle types
Apply - Classify triangles based on measurements
Analyze - Determine how side lengths affect angles

Council for Economic Education: Personal Finance Competency Areas

Evaluate student's ability to categorize their own real expenses
Quiz on explaining why specific items are categorized as needs or wants

title: MicroSim PCA Map

creator: Dan McCreary
subject: Systems Thinking
Ethics
Policy Design
Leverage Points

educationalMetadata.topic: Donella Meadows' 12 Leverage Points for System Intervention
learningObjectives: Understand the hierarchy of intervention effectiveness in complex systems
Recognize why surface-level interventions often fail to create lasting change
Identify which leverage level is appropriate for different change strategies
Navigate to detailed explanations of each leverage point
educationalMetadata.prerequisites: Basic understanding of systems thinking concepts

accessibility.screenReader: Canvas description provided via describe() function
accessibility.colorContrast: High contrast text, zone colors distinguishable

controls.description: Hover over iceberg layers to see detailed information in the right panel
Click any layer to navigate to its detailed explanation in Chapter 6

visualElements.name: Iceberg
visualElements.description: Left side visualization showing 10 leverage point layers with animated waterline

visualElements.name: Info Panel
visualElements.description: Right side panel showing layer details on hover or introduction text by default

visualElements.name: Zone Legend
visualElements.description: Color-coded legend showing Shallow, Structural, Deep, and Transformative zones

assumptions: Leverage points are hierarchical with deeper points being more effective
The iceberg metaphor accurately represents visibility vs effectiveness tradeoff
limitations: Levels 2 and 3 are combined with Level 4 for simplicity
Actual effectiveness depends heavily on context and implementation
